list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Consider the line $L_1$ which passes through the points $A (-4,-4)$ and $B(8,-1)$.

- Find the gradient of the line$L_1$.[1]

Line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through the point $(-a,2a)$ where $a \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Given that$L_2$intersects the$y$-axis at$y=2a-3$, find the value of$a$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the formula for the gradient of a line
$$
 \begin{align*}    m&=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\end{align*}
$$
we can find the gradient of $L_1$
$$
 \begin{align*}    m_1&=\frac{-1-(-4)}{8-(-4)}\\[9pt]   &=\frac{3}{12}\\[9pt]   &=\answer{\dfrac{1}{4}}\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}    \end{align*}
$$

- As $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ we can find the gradient of $L_2$ using the formula
$$
\begin{align*}    m_1\times m_2&=-1\\[9pt]    \frac{1}{4}\times m_2&=-1\\[9pt]    m_2&=-4\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(A1)}}}\end{align*}
$$
We can form an equation, using the gradient formula, and solve for $a$.Substituting in $m_2$ and the points $(-a,2a)$ and $(0,2a-3)$ we get
$$
\begin{align*}m_2&=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\\[9pt]-4&=\frac{(2a-3)-2a}{0-(-a)}\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{(M1)}}}\\[9pt]  -4 &=\frac{-3}{a}\\[9pt]-4a&=-3\\[6pt] a&=\answer{\dfrac{3}{4}}\tag*{\textbf{\textcolor{black}{A1}}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^3$ and $g(x) = 2x - 1$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2]

- Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2]

- Solve the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]g(y) &= x \\[12pt]2y - 1 &= x \\[12pt]2y &= x + 1 \\[6pt]y &= \dfrac{x + 1}{2} \hspace{1.9em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x+1}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]&= g(x^3) \\[6pt]&\answer{= 2x^3-1} \hspace{1.1em}\end{aligned}
$$

- Solving the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{5.5em} 2x^3-1 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b)}] \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{12.2em} \answer{x \approx 0.794} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ and $g(x) = x - 3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $f(3)$. [2]

- Find $(g\circ f)(3)$. [2]

- Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ for $x = 3$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{0.6em} f(3) &= 3^2 + 2 \\[6pt]&= 9 + 2 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 11}\end{aligned}
$$

- Evaluating $(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x))$ for $x = 3$, we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{6.4em} (g\circ f)(3) &= g(f(3)) \\[6pt]&= g(11) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]&= 11 - 3 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 8}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we find
$$
\begin{aligned}g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]g(y) &= x \\[6pt]y - 3 &= x \\[6pt]y &= x + 3 \hspace{2.1em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{g^{-1}(x) = x+3} \hspace{0.8em}
$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 4x - 3$ and $g(x) = 2x$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Write down the value of $g(5)$. [1]

- Find $(f\circ g)(x)$. [2]

- Find $(f\circ g)^{-1}(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{g(5) = 10}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(f\circ g)(x) &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]&= f(2x) \\[6pt]&= 4(2x) - 3 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 8x - 3}\end{aligned}
$$

- Let $h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)$.
Hence $h^{-1}(x) = (f\circ g)^{-1}(x)$.If we solve the equation $(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = h^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]h(y) &= x \\[12pt]8y - 3 &= x \\[12pt]8y &= x + 3 \\[6pt]y &= \dfrac{x + 3}{8} \hspace{1.8em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{(f\circ g)^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x + 3}{8}} \hspace{2.7em}
$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $-3\leq x\leq 4$ is shown in the following diagram.

- Write down the value of$f(2)$.[1]

Let $g(x)=2f(x)-1$ for $-3\leq x\leq 4$.

- On the axes above, sketch the graph of $g$. [2]

- Hence determine the value of $(g\circ f)(2) $. [1]

- Hence solve the equation $(f\circ g)(x)=0$ when $x>0$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x)$ when $x=2$

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/c72e725f-d507-4121-a17b-66ecf4396773/AA1269-a1.JPEG)

Hence $\tcbhighmath{f(2)=1}$.
$$
\begin{align*}   \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- The function $f(x)$ is mapped to $g(x)$ by two transformations.By considering $g(x)=\textcolor{blue}{2}f(x)\textcolor{green}{-1}$, we can see there is a $\text{\textcolor{blue}{vertical stretch by a scale factor of}}\,\,\textcolor{blue}{2}$ and a $\text{\textcolor{green}{vertical shift down}}\,\textcolor{green}{1}\,\text{\textcolor{green}{unit}}$.The vertical stretch ($\textcolor{blue}{y=2f(x)}$) is shown in blue below.Note that the vertical distance from the $y$-axis of every point on the curve is doubled.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/41efdd00-fe18-4d90-9631-5f9a1149eef3/AA1269-a2.JPEG)

Then the vertical shift is shown in green ($\textcolor{green}{y=2f(x)-1}$) .Note that every point on the blue curve is shifted vertically down $1$ unit.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/51af6fb3-badd-4b23-be15-204b433352af/AA1269-a3.JPEG)

Correct local minimum at $(-2,1)$
$$
    \begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}    \end{align*}
$$
Correct $y$-intercept at $(0,5)$
$$
    \begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}    \end{align*}
$$

- From part (a) we know that $f(2)=1$.
$$
\begin{align*}    (g\circ f)(2)&=g(f(2))\end{align*}
$$
Hence
$$
\begin{align*}    &=g(1)\\[6pt]    &=3\end{align*}
$$
Hence $\tcbhighmath{(g\circ f)(2)=3}$.
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Here is the graph of $g(x)$ showing that $g(1)=3$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/d9677404-62bb-4ed2-94e5-6951c683bf6f/AA1269-a4.JPEG)


- We have the equation $(f\circ g)(x)=0$. The L.H.S. is a composite function which can be rewritten
$$
\begin{align*}    (f\circ g)(x)&= f(\textcolor{red}{g(x)})\end{align*} 
$$
Here we can see that $\textcolor{red}{g(x)}$ is the inner function and $f(x)$ is the outer function, meaning that the output of $g$ will be the input of $f$.By considering the graph of $f(x)$ we see that when $x=3$ then $f(x)=0$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/1d572c1f-c5a2-405c-ad40-af9f075ac80d/AA1269-a5.JPEG)

This means in order to have an output of $0$, the input must be $3$.
$$
\begin{align*}    f(\textcolor{red}{g(x)})=0\\[6pt]    f(\textcolor{red}{3})=0\end{align*}
$$
Therefore we need to find the value of $x$, where $x>0$, such that $g(x)=3$.From part (c), we know that $g(1)=3$, and we can see that this is the only possible solution when $x>0$.Hence if $x>0$ and $(f\circ g)(x)=0$ then $\answer{x=1}$.
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2x$, $g(x) = 4x + 6$ and $h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)$, for
$x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $h(x)$. [2]

- Find $h^{-1}(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.3em} h(x) &= (f\circ g)(x) \\[6pt]&= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]&= f(4x+6) \\[6pt]&= 2(4x+6) \\[6pt]&\answer{= 8x+12}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we solve the equation $(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = h^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]h(y) &= x \\[12pt]8y+12 &= x \\[12pt]8y &= x-12 \\[6pt]y &= \dfrac{x-12}{8} \hspace{1.3em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{h^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-12}{8}}
$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \sqrt{x-3}$, for $x \geq 3$.

- Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [2]


Let $g(x) = x^2 +1$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $(g\circ f)(28)$. [2]

- Write down the range of:
- $f^{-1}$;
- $g$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[7pt]f(y) &= x \\[5pt]\sqrt{y - 3} &= x \\[6pt]y - 3 &= x^2 \\[6pt]y &= x^2 + 3 \hspace{1.7em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{f^{-1}(x) = x^2 + 3} \hspace{0.4em}
$$

- Evaluating $f(x) = \sqrt{x - 3}$ for $x = 28$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1em} f(28) &= \sqrt{28-3} \\[6pt]&= \sqrt{25} \\[8pt]&= 5\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we find
$$
\begin{aligned}(g\circ f)(28) &= g(f(28)) \\[7pt]&= g(5) \\[6pt]&= 5^2 +1 \hspace{2.2em} \\[7pt]&\answer{= 26} \end{aligned}
$$

- 
- $\answer{[3,\infty)}$
- $\answer{[1,\infty)}$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Two functions, $f$ and $g$, are defined in the following table.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a18c1edb-e266-48ea-9409-91450ee6259e/images/72fb6a0c-ca68-40db-a765-15cc4604525e/f16cb92d520a6fc6d08cc849fc6b256348e1335f.svg)



- Write down the value of $f(2)$. [1]

- Find the value of $(g\circ f)(2)$. [2]

- Find the value of $g^{-1}(5)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(2) = 0}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(g\circ f)(2) &= g(f(2)) \\[6pt]&= g(0) \\[6pt]&\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(g\circ g^{-1})(5) &= 5 \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]g(g^{-1}(5)) &= 5 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{9.7em} \answer{g^{-1}(5) = -4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $g(-4) = 5$}]
$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Let $f(x)=4x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- The graph of a linear function $g$ is perpendicular to the graph of $f$ and passes through the origin. Find an expression for $g(x)$.[2]

- The graph of a linear function $h$ is parallel to the graph of $f$ and passes through the point $(3,4)$. Find an expression for $h(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The slope of $f$ is $m_f=4$, then $m_g=-\dfrac{1}{4}$ is the slope of the function $g$ that is perpendicular to $f$, we have
$$
\begin{align*}y-y_1&=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt] y-0&=-\dfrac{1}{4}(x-0)\\[6pt] y&=-\dfrac{1}{4}x\end{align*}
$$
Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{g(x)=-\dfrac{1}{4}x}.$
- The slope of the function $h$ is $m_h=4$ because $h$ is parallel to the graph $f$. We have,
$$
\begin{align*}y-y_1=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt]y-4&=4(x-3)\\[6pt]y-4&=4x-12\\[6pt]y=4x-8\end{align*}
$$
Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{h(x)=4x-8}.$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
The equation of a line $L_1$ is $2x + 3y = -5$.

- Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2]


A second line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$.

- State the gradient of $L_2$. [1]


The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L_2$.

- Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [2]


The point Q is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$.

- Find the coordinates of Q.[3]
list.markScheme:
- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have
$$
\begin{aligned}2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = -\dfrac{2}{3}}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]&= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]&\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
$$

- Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m = 3/2$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]2y &= 3x - 12 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \hspace{3em}{(1)} \\[6pt]L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \hspace{3.25em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$
Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{-0.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}x &=& 2 \\[6pt]y &=& -3\end{array}\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,-3)}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \sqrt{x+7}$, for $x \geq -7$.

- Find $f^{-1}(3)$. [3]


Let $g$ be a function such that $g^{-1}$ exists for all real numbers.

- Given that$g(9) = 4$, find$(f\circ g^{-1})(4)$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(3) = 3$ for
$y = f^{-1}(3)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(3)) &= 3 \hspace{3.8em} \\[6pt]f(y) &= 3 \\[4pt]\sqrt{y + 7} &= 3 \\[6pt]y + 7 &= 9 \\[6pt]y &= 2 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{f^{-1}(3) = 2} \hspace{2.4em}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}4 &= g(9) \\[6pt]g^{-1}(4) &= g^{-1}(g(9)) \\[6pt]\hspace{11em} g^{-1}(4) &= 9 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{since $(g^{-1}\hspace{-0.1em}\circ g)(9) = 9$}]\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}(f\circ g^{-1})(4) &= f(g^{-1}(4)) \hspace{0.9em} \\[8pt]&= f(9) \\[6pt]&= \sqrt{9+7} \\[6pt]&= \sqrt{16} \\[8pt]&\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ and $g(x) = x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $f(2)$. [2]

- Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [2]

- Solve $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ for $x = 2$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.6em} f(2) &= 2^3 + 1 \\[6pt]&= 8 + 1 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 9}\end{aligned}
$$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we find
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{0.6em} f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]f(y) &= x \\[6pt]y^3 + 1 &= x \\[6pt]y^3 &= x - 1 \\[5pt]y &= \sqrt[3]{x-1} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{2em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x-1}}
$$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}f(g(x)) &= 0 \\[7pt]f(x-2) &= 0 \\[6pt]\hspace{4.6em} (x-2)^3 + 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]x-2 &= \sqrt[3]{-1} \hspace{3em} [=-1] \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{1.7em} \answer{x = 1}
$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Let $f(x) = (x+2)^3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [3]


Let $g$ be a function so that $(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6$.

- Find$g(x)$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[7pt]f(y) &= x \\[6pt](y+2)^3 &= x \\[6pt]y+2 &= \sqrt[3]{x} \\[6pt]y &= \sqrt[3]{x} - 2 \hspace{1.1em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{0.3em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x} - 2}
$$

- If we solve the equation $(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6$ for $y = g(x)$, we
obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}f(g(x)) &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]f(y) &= 27x^6 \\[6pt](y+2)^3 &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]y+2 &= 3x^2 \\[6pt]y &= 3x^2 - 2 \hspace{0.1em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{1.5em} \answer{g(x) = 3x^2 - 2}
$$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of $y = f(x)$, for
$-1 \leq x \leq 2$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/ee08b3c6-49a0-41f7-814f-bb4d9079b11c/ccc9d5942ccfefc2e6313a34922fed1ada13594f.svg)



- Write down the value of:
- $f(1)$;
- $f^{-1}(-2)$. [2]


- Find $(f\circ f)(1)$. [2]

- Sketch the graph of $y = f(-x)$ on the same grid above. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
- $\answer{f(1) = 2}$
- $\answer{f^{-1}(-2) = -1}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(f\circ f)(1) &= f(f(1)) \\[6pt]&= f(2) \\[6pt]&\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
$$

- The graph of $y = f(-x)$ is a reflection of the graph of $y = f(x)$
in the $y$-axis.Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f(-x)$ on the same grid below,
we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/64f14811-163b-49f4-8bcc-e95f5b9a1d96/d2b3518aa3484d1ffd19b0a1dd3f20d6f92c6046.svg)

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
- Express $2x^2 - 8x + 9$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where
$a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2]

- Given that $f(x) = x - 2$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 9$, find
$g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}2x^2 - 8x + 9 &= 2\big[x^2 - 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]&= 2\big[(x-2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]&= 2(x-2)^2 - 8 + 9 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 2(x-2)^2 + 1}\end{aligned}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{8.3em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 2x^2 - 8x + 9 \\[6pt]g(f(x)) &=  2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]g(x-2) &= 2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x - 2$}] \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{g(x) = 2x^2 + 1} \hspace{3.4em}
$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
The area, $A$, of a given square can be represented by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}A(P) &= \dfrac{P^2}{16}, \hspace{0.5em} P \geq 0,\end{aligned}
$$

where
$P$ is the perimeter of the square.
The graph of the function $A$, for $0 \leq P \leq 20$, is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46346d59-3adc-4e1d-9102-a09321b02eea/images/ff39b657-e430-4f20-b9ef-fcc41c30e921/8c2c1a298c1b79e92e64f94fe2b4a4d452e488ad.svg)



- Find the value of $A(20)$. [1]

- On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$.
[3]

- In the context of the question, explain the meaning of
$A^{-1}(4) = 8$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $A(P)$ for $P = 20$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}A(P) &= \dfrac{20^2}{16} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]&\answer{= 25}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $A^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46346d59-3adc-4e1d-9102-a09321b02eea/images/1a31c9ea-d742-4abc-b00b-5af09583611b/508588bd8662a40575516587374d1e3379be6249.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given square, when the area is \(4\), the perimeter is \(8\)}}$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \sqrt[3]{2x+1}$, for
$-14 \leq x \leq 13$.

- Write down the range of $f$. [2]

- Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [2]

- Write down the domain and range of $f^{-1}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
1 $f$ is continuous and increasing;2 $f(-14) = -3$ and $f(13) = 3$.Hence the range of $f$ is
$\answer{[-3,3]}$
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[13pt]f\left(y\right) &= x \\[12pt]\sqrt[3]{2y+1} &= x \\[12pt]2y+1 &= x^3 \\[6pt]y &= \dfrac{x^3 - 1}{2} \hspace{1.3em}\end{aligned}
$$
Hence an
expression for $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x^3 - 1}{2}}$
- The domain and range of $f^{-1}$ are
$$
\begin{aligned}\text{domain}: & \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{[-3,3]} \\[8pt]\text{range}: & \hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{[-14,13]}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function

$$
P(D) = \dfrac{D}{10}+1
$$

where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea
level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres.
A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the
function

$$
D(t) = 10+5t
$$

where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is
the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in
metres.

- Find the composite function $P\circ D$ and explain what it means in
the
context of this question[3]

- Find and interpret $(P\circ D)(10)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The composite function can be expressed as
$$
\begin{aligned}(P\circ D) (t) &= P(D(t)) \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\&= P(10+5t)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\&= \dfrac{10+5t}{10}+1 \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\&\hspace{0.28em}\answer{= 2+\dfrac{t}{2}}\rule[-5.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\hspace{6em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{\text{This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time $t$ minutes.}}
$$

- Substituting $t=10$ in (1), we get
$$
\begin{aligned}(P\circ D)(10)&=2+\dfrac{10}{2}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\&\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=7}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{\text{This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.}}
$$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$.

- On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3]


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)


- Find the coordinates of:
- the $x$-intercept;
- the $y$-intercept. [2]



The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$.

- Find$g(x)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $y = f(x)$ for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)


- 
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(0.996,0)}$
- Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}y &= f(0) \\[6pt]&= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]&\approx -2.52\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,-2.52)}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]&= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]&\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it
produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function

$$
N(t)=3t-9
$$

where $t$
is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3
hours.
The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of
tyres produced, and is modelled by the function

$$
P(N)=60N-850
$$

where
$N$ is the number of tyres produced.

- Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per
day.[2]

- Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per
day, $t$.[2]

- Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the
factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer
to the nearest hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}N(6) &= 3(6)-9 = 9\\\end{aligned}
$$
Thus, the profit is given by P(9)
$$
\begin{aligned} P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310 \end{aligned}
$$
Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$\answer{\$\hspace{0.07em}-310}$
- The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P\circ N$. Hence, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}(P\circ N)(t) &= P(N(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\&= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\&= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\&\hspace{-5em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\hspace{5em}{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
$$

- The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}(P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
$$
Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$\answer{8}$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The circumference, $C$, of a given circle can be represented by the
function

$$
\begin{aligned}C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{A}{\pi}}, \hspace{0.5em} A \geq 0,\end{aligned}
$$

where $A$ is the area of the circle.
The graph of the function $C$, for $0 \leq A \leq 24$, is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f456fc19-890c-4269-962e-6613e63c4f7d/images/1e281987-3b8b-4dcc-809b-86850ebedbb5/3388e210bb4d6f02426816cb2651396f2822c4c1.svg)



- Find the value of $C(24)$. [1]

- On the grid above, draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$.
[3]

- In the context of the question, explain the meaning of
$C^{-1}(2\pi) = \pi$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $C(A)$ for $A = 24$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}C(A) &= 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{24}{\pi}} \\[6pt]&\answer{\approx 17.4}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we draw the graph of the inverse function, $C^{-1}$, on the grid
below, we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f456fc19-890c-4269-962e-6613e63c4f7d/images/4d19e261-35fc-454f-b0a3-35e2cd9aa8c3/fae26733051cc1a7c15c3478abb0d0697e69d7fa.svg)


- $\answer{\text{For a given circle, when the circumference is \(2\pi\), the area is \(\pi\)}}$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
The functions $f$ and $g$ are defined such that $f(x) = \dfrac{x-2}{3}$
and $g(x) = 12x+4$.

- Show that $(g\circ f)(x) = 4x-4$. [2]

- Given that $(g\circ f)^{-1}(a) = 10$, find the value of $a$.
[3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= g\hspace{0.05em}(f(x)) \\[9pt]&= g\Big(\dfrac{x-2}{3}\Big) \\[5pt]&= 12\Big(\dfrac{x-2}{3}\Big)+4 \\[9pt]&= 4\hspace{0.05em}(x-2) + 4 \\[13pt]&= 4x-4\end{aligned}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3.25em} (g\circ f)^{-1}(a) &= 10 \\[6pt](g\circ f)(10) &= a \\[6pt]4(10)-4 &= a \hspace{3em} [\text{by part $(a)$}] \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{a = 36}
$$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
- Express $3x^2 + 18x + 20$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where
$a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2]

- Given that $f(x) = x + 3$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 3x^2 + 18x + 20$,
find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}3x^2 + 18x + 20 &= 3\big[x^2 + 6x\big] + 20 \\[6pt]&= 3\big[(x+3)^2 - 9\big] + 20 \\[6pt]&= 3(x+3)^2 - 27 + 20 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 3(x+3)^2 - 7}\end{aligned}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{10.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 3x^2 + 18x + 20 \\[6pt]g(f(x)) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]g(x+3) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x + 3$}] \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{g(x) = 3x^2 - 7} \hspace{0.6em}
$$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
A town is planning to construct a jogging path in a grass field
$170$ m long and $70$ m
wide. The path is to be the shape of a rectangle with two semicircles of
radius $x$, as shown in the diagram. The sides of the rectangle
connecting the circles are to be $100$ m long.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/8c94d818-8318-43d4-a5bd-1126ae8aab6c/22448faee8b9c6574b3fdefa8505f67030a94583.svg)



- Write down a function, $P$, (in metres) for the perimeter of the
jogging path, in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]

- Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]

- Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$. Express your
answer in the form $P^{-1}(x)=mx+c$.[2]


The designers of the path are deciding whether the total length of the
path should be $300$ m,
$400$ m, or $500$ m. The
designers want to maximise the perimeter of the path, but fit the path
in the grass field.

- Determine which length is most suitable, given the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the path is the sum of the two straight sides
connecting the circles and the perimeter of a complete circle of
radius $x$. We get
$$
\answer{P(x) = 200+2\pi x}
$$

- The length of the path will be $100+2x$ and its width $2x$.
Therefore we require $100+2x\leq 170$ and $2x\leq 70$. Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}\answer{\text{Domain: } 0 < x \leq 35.}\\\end{aligned}
$$
For
the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=200$ and
$P(35)=200+70\pi$. We get
$$
\begin{aligned}\answer{\text{Range: } 200\leq P(x) \leq 200+70\pi.}\\\end{aligned}
$$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$
\begin{aligned}y &= 200+2\pi x\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\x &= 200+2\pi y\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\y &= \dfrac{x-200}{2\pi}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}x - \dfrac{100}{\pi}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
$$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the running
track can be calculated, as shown in the following table.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/282aeb49-7c34-4d6f-82ac-e270f942f1f3/8985560368df68be350c8eca5afbe5b19a733963.svg)

From the table, we can see that the largest perimeter of the options
that still fit inside the grass field dimensions is
$$
\answer{P=400\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
$$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Harry is planning on constructing a glass window in one of the outer
walls of his house. The dimensions of the wall space available are 2m x
2m. Harry wants the window to be in the shape shown in the diagram
below. The bottom section is a rectangle and the top part is a
semicircle of radius $x$ m. Harry wants the
height of the rectangle to be fixed at 1 m.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/1970cc7c-4fb4-47c4-8b78-0b174bc78816/4b81f49038bd3a70fed3ed55e752da67f426bdf2.svg)



- Write down a function $P$ (in metres) for the perimeter of the
window in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]

- Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the available wall.[2]

- Find an equation for the inverse function $P^{-1}(x)$.[2]


Harry wants to maximise the size of the window, however the window frame
that covers the perimeter of the window can only be 5, 6, or 7 metres
long, due to manufacturing restrictions.

- Determine which perimeter length is the best option for
Harry.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The perimeter for the window is the sum of the three sides of the
rectangle and the semicircle, thus we get
$$
\begin{aligned}P(x) &= \text{Rectangle width}+2\times\text{Rectangle height}+\text{Semicircle} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\&= 2x+2(1)+\dfrac{\cancel{2}\pi x}{\cancel{2}} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\&\hspace{-2.15em}\answer{P(x) = 2+(2+\pi)x}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
$$

- The width of the window will be $2x$ and the height $1+x$.
Therefore, we require $2x\leq 2$ and $1+x\leq 2$.
Hence
$$
\begin{aligned}\answer{\text{Domain: } 0\leq x \leq 1.}\\\end{aligned}
$$
Now
for the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=2$ and
$P(1)=4+\pi$. Therefore,
$$
\begin{aligned}\answer{\text{Range: } 2\leq P(x) \leq 4+\pi.}\\\end{aligned}
$$

- Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$
\begin{aligned}y &= 2+(2+\pi)x\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\x &= 2+(2+\pi)y\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\y &= \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\ &\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-2}{(2+\pi)}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
$$

- For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P^{-1}(P)$, then the length and width of the window
can be calculated, as shown in the following table

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/2db4d8fa-3dad-4595-94a4-c7663a5dbf7c/95900dceeb57876cf3bec3ce67dc138811471933.svg)

From the table, we can see that the perimeter that maximizes the
dimension of the window that fits in the wall is
$$
\answer{P=7\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}
$$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
Let $f(x) = e^x - 2$ and $g(x) = 3x + k$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$k$ is a constant.

- Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2]

- Given that
$\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) = -4$,
find the value of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]&= g(e^x - 2) \\[6pt]&= 3(e^x - 2) + k \\[6pt]&\answer{= 3e^x - 6 + k}\end{aligned}
$$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) &= -4 \hspace{6.9em} \\[4pt]\lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty}\hspace{-0.2em}\big[3e^x - 6 + k\big] &= -4 \\[4pt]3(0) - 6 + k &= -4 \\[9pt]- 6 + k &= -4 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{0.2em} \answer{k = 2}
$$

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x)=3e^{\frac{x}{2}}$ where $x \in \mathrm{R}$ and is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e175b6d9-563c-4c8f-a8fa-b8e3ca7ce99f/images/b05207b3-e706-477a-85d6-ff97ee420070/AA1180_q.JPEG)

$$

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e175b6d9-563c-4c8f-a8fa-b8e3ca7ce99f/images/1c0086c2-1f6d-4408-915e-db801b80aa78/AA1180_a.JPEG)

A1 Correct shape/asymptotes
A1 Correct intercept

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$, for $x > -2$. The diagram below shows
part of the graph of $f$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ca4f0d8-2c1b-4539-b90a-140704aebde0/images/41cb6db4-c952-44a9-a5d0-dc5fd6907d15/0b26b0e195f4a087c10216491d624f903712efff.svg)



- Find the coordinates of:
- the $x$-intercept;
- the $y$-intercept. [2]


- Find the equation of the vertical asymptote to the graph of $f$.
[2]

- Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the
$x$-axis and
the $y$-axis. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3.8em} \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2} &= 0 \\[4pt]x &= -1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$
- Evaluating $f(x)=\dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$ for $x = 0$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{0.4em} f(0) &= \dfrac{\ln 2}{2} \\[8pt] &\approx 0.347\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,0.347)}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\lim_{x \rightarrow 0^+} \ln x &= -\infty \hspace{3em} \\[7pt]\lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} \ln (x+2) &= -\infty \\[6pt]\lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} f(x) &= -\infty \\\end{aligned}
$$
Hence
the equation of the vertical asymptote is
$\answer{x = -2}$
- The area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis
and the $y$-axis is
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{10em} A &= \int_{-1}^0 \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}\,\mathrm{d}x \\[8pt]&\answer{\approx 0.193 \text{ units}^2} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
Helen is working with the function

$$
\begin{align*}    f(x)&=e^{-x}(x-2)^2\end{align*}
$$

where $x>0$.
She wants to learn more about its behaviour.

- Show that $f'(x)=-e^{-x}(x^2-6x+8)$. [2]

- Help Helen by finding $f''(x)$.[1]

- Hence, or otherwise find
- the exact coordinates of any stationary points.
- the nature of these stationary points.[6]



The function is concave down between $a<x<b$.

- Find$a$and$b$in the form$s \pm \sqrt{t}$where$s, t \in \mathbb{Z}$.[4]

Helen begins looking at another function $g(x)$.
She knows that $g(2)=5$ and $g'(2)=3$.

- Find the exact value of$[f(g(2))]'$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- We can differentiate the function using the product rule
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}    f'(x)&=(e^{-x})'(x-2)^2+e^{-x}((x-2)^2)'\\[6pt]    &=-e^{-x}(x-2)^2+2e^{-x}(x-2) \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Factorise out the $e^{-x}$ term and simplify
$$
\begin{align*}    &=-e^{-x}((x-2)^2-2(x-2))\\[6pt]    &=-e^{-x}(x^2-4x+4-2x+4)\\[6pt]    &\hspace{0.25em}\answer{=-e^{-x}(x^2-6x+8)} \hspace{2em} \text{... as required}\end{align*}
$$

- We can use the product rule again
$$
\begin{align*}    f''(x)&=(-e^{-x})'(x^2-6x+8)+(-e^{-x})(x^2-6x+8)'\\[6pt]    &=e^{-x}(x^2-6x+8)-e^{-x}(2x-6)\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]    &\hspace{0.25em}\answer{=e^{-x}(x^2-8x+14)}\end{align*}
$$

- 
- To find the $x-$coordinate of stationary points we must solve $f'(x)=0$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}    0&=-e^{-x}(x^2-6x+8)\\[6pt]    0&=-e^{-x}(x-2)(x-4)\end{align*}
$$
With the function fully factorised we can solve for $x$
$$
\begin{align*}    -e^{-x}=0&&\hspace{1.8em} &x-2=0&x-4=0&\\[6pt]    \text{no solution}&& &\hspace{1.8em}x=2&x=4& \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
We can see that there are $2$ stationary points at $x=2$ and $x=4$.Next we can find the $y-$coordinate of these two points.
$$
\begin{align*}    f(2)=e^{-2}(2-2)^2 & &f(4)=e^{-4}(4-2)^2\\[6pt]    f(2)=0 & &f(4)=4e^{-4}\end{align*}
$$
The exact coordinates of the two stationary points are
$$
\begin{align*}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(2, 0) \text{ and } (4, 4e^{-4})} \tag*{\textbf{A1A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- To classify the stationary points we can evaluate $f''(x)$ at the stationary points.If $f''(x_{\text{stat point}}) > 0$, the S.P. is a minimum, and if $f''(x_{\text{stat point}}) < 0$, the S.P. is a maximum.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}    f''(2)&=e^{-2}(2^2-8\times 2+14) & &f''(4)=e^{-4}(4^2-8\times 4+14)\\[6pt]    f''(2)&=2e^{-2} & &f''(4)=-2e^{-4}\\[6pt]    f''(2)&>0 \hspace{1em} \text{... minimum}& &f''(4)<0 \hspace{1em} \text{... maximum}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(2, 0) \text{ is a minimum and } (4, 4e^{-4}) \text{ is a maximum.}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$


- When a function changes concavity we know that $f''(x)=0$.
$$
\begin{align*}   f''(x)&=e^{-x}(x^2-8x+14)\\[6pt]   &=0\end{align*}
$$
$e^{-x}\neq 0$ therefore we can use $x^2-8x+14$ to learn about the concavity.The original function $f(x)$ is concave down when $f''(x)<0$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{R1}}\end{align*}
$$
We can make a rough sketch of $y=x^2-8x+14$, recognising the region of the graph which is below zero. This is shown as the solid line.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0bc762d2-1c0a-4382-bc4d-446bb07fc04f/images/94b1bb7d-77f9-4402-970b-2624ab949cbe/AA1153_a.JPEG)

Hence, between the roots, $a$ and $b$, will be the region for which $f(x)$ is concave down.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$
To find $a$ and $b$ we can use the quadratic formula.
$$
\begin{align*}   0&=x^2-8x+14\\[6pt]   x&=\frac{-(-8)\pm \sqrt{(-8)^2-4\times1 \times 14}}{2\times 1}\tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\[6pt]   x&=\frac{8\pm \sqrt{8}}{2}\\[6pt]   x&=4\pm \sqrt{2}\end{align*}
$$
As $b>a$ then we can say that $f(x)$ is concave down in the region
$$
\begin{align*}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{4-\sqrt2 < x< 4+\sqrt 2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- Using the chain rule we can differentiate $f(g(x))$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}       [f(g(x))]'&=f'(g(x))\times g'(x)\end{align*}
$$
Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}       [f(g(2))]'&=f'(g(2))\times g'(2)\end{align*}
$$
We were given $g'(2)=3$ and $g(2)=5$, hence
$$
\begin{align*}       [f(g(2))]' &=f'(5)\times 3 \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Using part (b) we can find $f'(5)$
$$
\begin{align*}   f'(5)&=-e^{-5}(5^2-6\times 5+8)\\[6pt]&=-e^{-5}(3)\\[6pt]&=-3e^{-5}\end{align*}
$$
Hence we can evaluate $[f(g(x))]'$
$$
\begin{align*}[f(g(x))]'&=f'(5)\times 3 \\[6pt]&=-3e^{-5}\times 3 \\[6pt]&\hspace*{-4.35em}\answer{[f(g(x))]'=-9e^{-5}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x) = \sqrt{\dfrac{6+2x}{6-2x}}$, for
$-3 \leq x < 3$.
Find the inverse function of $f$, stating its domain and range.
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we get

$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[16pt]f(y) &= x \\[11pt]\sqrt{\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y}} &= x \\[6pt]\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y} &= x^2 \\[12pt]6 + 2y &= 6x^2-2x^2y \\[16pt]3 + y &= 3x^2-x^2y \\[16pt](x^2 + 1)y &= 3x^2 - 3 \\[12pt]y &= \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1} \hspace{3em}  \\\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the
inverse function of $f$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) =  \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1}}$
The domain of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[0,\infty)}$
and range of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[-3,3)}$

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]
The function $f(x)=a\sin{(bx)}+c$ where $0 \leq x \leq \pi$ and $a,b,c \in \mathrm{R}$ is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/0547420d-b08d-4f9e-bd37-d903d3be790b/AA1154.JPEG)


The coordinates of the first two stationary points are $(\tfrac{\pi}{6}, -1)$ and $(\tfrac{\pi}{2},3)$ respectively.

- Find
- a.
- c.
- b. [5]



The domain of $f(x)$ is restricted to $\tfrac{\pi}{2}\leq x \leq k$, where $k \in \mathrm{R}$. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.

- Find the largest possible value of$k$.[2]

Another function is defined as $g(x)=-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3$.

- Determine the coordinates of thefirstmaximum value of$g(x)$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- 
- To find the value of $a$, which is known as the amplitude, we must find half of the vertical distance between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/a928181a-4fcd-4ea9-b71e-dc8f5cea02c9/AA1154a.JPEG)

We can see from the diagram that the curve is a reflection of $\sin{x}$ in the $x-$axis, therefore the value of $a$ must be negative.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    a&=-\frac{3-(-1)}{2}\\[6pt]    &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-2}  \tag*{\textbf{R1}}\end{align*}
$$

- To find the  value of $c$ we must find the $y-$value half way between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/f6143e17-9146-4ce4-9c33-b01bced64c56/AA1154b.JPEG)

Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    c&=\frac{3+(-1)}{2}\\[6pt]    &=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{1}  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- To find $b$ we use the formula $T=\frac{2\pi}{b}$.We can use the diagram to find $T$ and see that $\frac{T}{2}$ is the $x-$distance between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/c7dc5b6a-813a-4ffb-bafd-b8fb49ff2f45/AA1154c%20(1).JPEG)

Hence
$$
\begin{align*}    \frac{T}{2}&=\left(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-\tfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\\[6pt]    T&=2\left(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-\tfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\\[6pt]    T&=\frac{2\pi}{3} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Using this value of $T$ and the formula stated above we can find $b$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \frac{2\pi}{3}&=\frac{2\pi}{b}\\[6pt]    b&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$


- For an inverse to exist the function must be one-to-one, this means it must pass the horizontal line test. We can see this is satisfied by the red part of $f(x)$  shown below
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/2b4f5cbc-7374-4bd7-a0b3-ee6657792bc7/AA1154inv.JPEG)

We can see that if we add one complete time period to $\tfrac{\pi}{6}$ we will get $k$, hence
$$
\begin{align*}	k&=\tfrac{\pi}{6}+\tfrac{2\pi}{3}\\[6pt]	&=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\tfrac{5\pi}{6}}  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- First we split the vertical and horizontal transformations.The inner function of $f$ is the horizontal transformations and everything else is vertical.
$$
\begin{align*}	&-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3\\[6pt]	&\text{Vertical}& \hspace{1em} & \text{Horizontal}\\[6pt]	&\times -2 & \hspace{1em} & \div 2\\[6pt]	&+3 & \hspace{1em} &\end{align*}
$$
Lets do the vertical transformations first. We don't need to transform the entire function. It is easier to identify a single point and transform that.Notice that we are multiplying by a negative number, that means $g$ will be a vertical reflection of $f$.Therefore the first maximum point of $g$ will be the image of the transformation of the first minimum point of $f$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$
Therefore we need to apply our transformations to the point $(\tfrac{\pi}{6},-1)$.We transform the $y$-coordinate by $\times -2$ and then $+3$, therefore the transformed $y$-coordinate is $-1\times-2+3=5$.We transform the $x$-coordinate by $\times\tfrac{1}{1/2}$.therefore the transformed $x$-coordinate is $\tfrac{\pi}{6}\times2=\tfrac{\pi}{3}$.Therefore $\answer{\text{the first maximum of }g(x)\text{ has coordinates }(\tfrac{\pi}{3}, 5).}$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{A1A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{4}x^2 - 2$ and $g(x) = x^2 - 4$, for
$x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Show that $(f\circ g)(x) = \dfrac{1}{4}x^4 - 2x^2 + 2$. [2]

- On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$, for
$0 \leq x \leq 3$. [3]




![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/ceb2f6e6-5725-4682-8f4f-1fb5b9e8117e/b4ef7d37b745cb564b996b9d79dff67b636cf799.svg)



- The equation$(f\circ g)(x) = k$has exactly two solutions,
for$0 \leq x \leq 3$. Findthe possible values of$k$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}(f\circ g)(x) &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]&= f(x^2 - 4) \\[6pt]\hspace{3em} &= \dfrac{1}{4}(x^2 - 4)^2 - 2 \\[6pt]&= \dfrac{1}{4}(x^4 - 8x^2+16) - 2 \\[6pt]&\answer{= \dfrac{1}{4}x^4 - 2x^2 + 2}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we draw the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/3cea73bc-198a-4cce-8863-df5d6b4c9bb7/35e596bf685bd72ab7dad8286b0830ba0c592c52.svg)


- The line $y = k$ intersects the graph of $y = (f \circ g)(x)$
exactly at two points when $-2 < k \leq 2$.Hence the equation $(f \circ g)(x) = k$ has exactly two solutions
when  $\answer{-2 < k \leq 2}$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Let $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$, for $x \neq -1$.

- For the graph of$f$, find:
- the $x$-intercept;
- the $y$-intercept;
- the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5]



Let $g(x) = x-3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$
intersect at points A and B.

- Find the coordinates of A and B. [5]

- Find the equation of the straight line that passes through
A and B,
giving your answer in the form $y = mx + c$. [3]

- Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular
to the line
passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
- Since the equation $f(x) = 0$ has no solutions, there are
$\answer{\text{no \(x\)-intercepts}}$
- Evaluating $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$ for $x = 0$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}f(0) &= \dfrac{5}{0+1} \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]&= 5\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,5)}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}&= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]x &= -1\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Solving the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2em} \dfrac{5}{x+1} &= x-3 \\[6pt]5 &= (x+1)(x-3) \\[9pt]5 &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[9pt]0 &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[10pt]0 &= (x+2)(x-4) \\[10pt]x &= -2,\hspace{0.25em}4 \\\end{aligned}
$$
Evaluating $g(x) = x-3$
for $x = -2$ and $x = 4$, we find
$$
\hspace{3.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}y &=& g(-2) &=& -5 \\[9pt]y &=& g(4) &=& 1\end{array}
$$
Hence we find
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(-2,-5)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(4,1)}$
- Using the gradient formula with A$(-2,-5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}m_{\mathrm{AB}} &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[6pt]&= \dfrac{1-(-5)}{4-(-2)} \\[10pt]&= 1\end{aligned}
$$
Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(-2,-5)$ and $m = 1$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]\hspace{0.15em} y - (-5) &= (1)(x-(-2)) \\[6pt]y + 5 &= x + 2 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{y = x-3} \hspace{0.15em}
$$

- $\answer{m_{\perp\mathrm{AB}} = -1}$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
- Write down the domain and range of the logarithmic function
$y = \log_a x$
where $a > 0$ and $a \neq 1$. [2]

- Given that $\log_{x^2} y = 9 \log_y (x^2)$, find all the possible
expressions
of $y$ as a function of $x$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\text{domain}:\hspace{0.75em}&\hspace{0.525em}\answer{(0,\infty)} \hspace{1.8em} \\[8pt]\text{range}:\hspace{0.75em}&\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\mathbb{R}}\end{aligned}
$$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}\log_{x^2} y &= 9 \log_y (x^2) \\[11pt]\hspace{4em} \dfrac{\ln y}{\ln (x^2)} &= \dfrac{9\ln (x^2)}{\ln y} \\[6pt]\dfrac{\ln y}{2\ln x} &= \dfrac{18\ln x}{\ln y} \\[12pt](\ln y)^2 &= (6\ln x)^2 \\[16pt]\ln y &= \pm 6\ln x \\[16pt]\ln y &= \ln (1/x^6)\hspace{0.25em}\text{ or }\hspace{0.25em}\ln (x^6) \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{2.2em} \answer{y = \dfrac{1}{x^6}\hspace{0.25em}\text{ or }\hspace{0.25em}x^6}
$$

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=6x^2-7x+2$.

- Fully factorise$f(x)$.[2]


Another function is defined as $g(x)=\ln x$.
A third function is defined as $h(x)=(g \circ f)(x)$.

- Hence, determine the domain of$h(x)$.[3]


The value $a$ is added to $f(x)$, where $a \in \mathrm{R}$.
For the domain of $h(x)$ to be $x \in \mathrm{R}$ then $a>k$.
The minimum value of $k$ is $a_{\text{min}}$.

- Find$a_{\text{min}}$[3]


Now the value $b$ is added to $f(x)$, where $b \in \mathrm{R}$ and $b > a_{\text{min}}$.

- Find the value of$b$such that the vertex of$h(x)$lies on the$x-$axis. Give your answer to$4$significant figures.[3]
list.markScheme:
- We will use the grouping method to factorise.
$$
\begin{align*}    a \times c &= 2 \times 6\\[6pt]     &=12\end{align*}
$$
Therefore we need to find two numbers that sum to $-7$ and multiply to give $12$. These are $-3$ and $-4$.Therefore, we can then rewrite $-7x$ as $-3x-4x$. Hence
$$
\begin{align*}    6x^2-7x+2&=6x^2-3x-4x+2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\end{align*}
$$
We then factorise the resulting expression into two groups
$$
\begin{align*}    &=3x(2x-1)-2(2x-1)\\[6pt]    &=\answer{(2x-1)(3x-2)} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- This is a composite function in which we form $h(x)$ by substituting $f(x)$ into $g(x)$. Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    h(x)&=\ln{\left(6x^2-7x+2\right)} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
We can now sketch $h(x)$ on our G.D.C.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/af7c0b7c-4bcd-4f99-bacf-0b4ca2abe01e/AA1169_a%20(2).JPEG)

$h(x)$ has two vertical asymptotes and these occur when $h(x)=\ln{0}$. Hence $f(x)=0$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\end{align*}
$$
Using the answer from part (a) we can find their equations.
$$
\begin{align*}    (2x-1)(3x-2)&=0\\[6pt]    x&=\tfrac{1}{2}, \tfrac{2}{3}\end{align*}
$$
The red arrows on the image above show the domain of $h(x)$.Therefore the $\answer{\text{domain of }h(x)\text{ is }x<\tfrac{1}{2}\text{ and }x>\tfrac{2}{3}}$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- The following image shows $f(x)$ and $h(x)$ together on the same axes.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/864e7db3-f2fc-45ed-ae8d-6c54c1f1a58c/AA1169_c%20(3).JPEG)

Notice that $h(x)$ is undefined when $f(x)<0$, this is the dark blue part of $f(x)$.Hence we need to shift $f(x)$ vertically up $a$ units such that the vertex of $f(x)$ touches the $x-$axis at a single point.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{R1}}\end{align*}
$$
To do this we must find the minimum value of $f(x)$.Using a G.D.C. we can find the minimum point of $f(x)$ to be $(0.5833...,-0.04166...)$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{(A1)}}\end{align*}
$$
Hence $f(x)+0.04166...$ will ensure $f(x)$ intersects the $x-$axis at one point. Ensuring that $f(x)\geq 0$ for all $x$. This is shown below

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/f9e9a35b-66f6-4ba2-a644-2fcd2cd8379f/AA1169_d.JPEG)

Therefore if $a>0.04166...$ then $f(x)>0$ for all $x$ and the domain of $h(x)$ is $x \in \mathrm{R}$.Hence, $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{a_{\text{min}}=0.0417}$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- Notice from the image in the previous part, that the vertex of $h(x)$ lies on the same vertical line as $f(x)$.Therefore the equation of the vertical line is $x=0.5833...$ and the final position of the vertex of $h(x)$ must be on the $x-$axis. This is shown below.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\end{align*}
$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/2cb902a1-41ee-439b-9f07-b35d58eb8a60/AA1169_d2.JPEG)

Therefore we need to solve this equation
$$
\begin{align*}    h(0.5833...)&=0\\[6pt]    (g \circ (f(0.5833...)+b))&=0\\[6pt]    \ln{(f(0.5833...)+b)}&=0 \hspace{2em} (\ln{1}=0) \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]    f(0.5833...)+b&=1\end{align*}
$$
From part (c) we know that $f(0.5833...)=-0.04166...$ at the vertex of $f(x)$ therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    b&=1-(-0.04166...)\\[6pt]    &=1.04166...\end{align*}
$$
Therefore $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{b=1.042}\hspace{0.525em}$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^4 - x^3 - 5x^2 + 3x + 2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Solve the inequality $f(x) < 0$. [3]

- For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of the local
maximum point. Round your answers to three significant figures.
[3]


The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where
$a,b \in \mathbb{R}$.

- 
- Write down the smallest value of $a < 0$ and the largest value
of $b > 0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers
correct to three significant figures.
- For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$
and $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the
coordinates of the end points of each curve.
- Solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = -1$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/24541222-4ef2-4f83-8869-c493d5ca3b7d/9444e78d503e38688d4c8ecfe5c29f2d0705556f.svg)

From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(-\infty,-2)$, $(-0.414,1)$ and $(2.41,\infty)$, and negative on
$(-2,-0.414)$ and $(1,2.41)$.Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x) < 0$ is
$$
\begin{aligned}\answer{(-2,-0.414)\cup(1,2.41)}\end{aligned}
$$

- From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has a local
maximum at point B.Hence the coordinates of the local maximum point are
$\answer{(0.285, 2.43)}$
- 
- From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[-1.14,0.285]$ or $[0.285,1.87]$.
Hence $f$ has an inverse if
$\answer{a = -1.41}$
and  $\answer{b = 0.285}$
- The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is a reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = f^{-1}(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/81733c2d-4f9c-47f5-bd1c-45eb231fe561/b6185b0f42f1522008f7c0707456fd536c854029.svg)


- If we solve the equation $f^{-1}(x) = -1$ for $x$, we obtain
$$
\begin{aligned}f(f^{-1}(x)) &= f(-1) \hspace{4em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{10.7em} \answer{x = -4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(f^{-1}(x)) = x$}]
$$
